item.title: Middle East Crisis: Israel and Hezbollah Exchange Strikes Amid Fears of Escalation
item.description: The Israeli military said it had hit weapons facilities, prompting Hezbollah to target an Israeli base, as tit-for-tat strikes continued across the Lebanese border.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Russia Seeks to Turn Humbling Incursion Into Military Gains
item.description: Two weeks after Ukraine launched its surprise attack, Russian forces have recovered from the initial shock and are trying to use the expanding war to their battlefield advantage.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: An army recruiting poster in Kursk, Russia, last week.

item.title: China’s ‘Road Trip Auntie’ Is Ready for a New Milestone: Divorce
item.description: Su Min became an internet sensation for leaving behind an abusive husband to drive across China alone. Now she’s ending the marriage, but there will be a price.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Joy Dong

item.title: ‘Keyboard Warriors’ Who Stoked UK Riots Test the Limits of Free Speech
item.description: As hundreds of people appear in court for their role in recent anti-immigrant riots in Britain, several are accused of fueling disorder through online posts, raising questions about the limits of free speech.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Roland Lloyd Parry/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Smoke billowing from a fire started by protesters as riot police stand guard after disturbances near the Southport Islamic Society Mosque in northwest England, on July 30.

item.title: Four Bodies From Bayesian Yacht Found in Sicily
item.description: The discoveries came after the vessel went down this week in what some witnesses described as a waterspout, or a small tornado, during a violent downpour. No names were immediately released.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: A rescue boat of the Vigili del Fuoco, Italy’s firefighting corps, near Palermo, Sicily, on Tuesday, a day after the British-flagged luxury yacht Bayesian sank.

item.title: What’s in the Latest U.S. Proposal for a Gaza Cease-Fire?
item.description: The Biden administration is pushing for a deal between Israel and Hamas with renewed urgency after months of lagging talks. Here’s a closer look at what the main differences appear to be.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Searching through rubble in Gaza City on Tuesday after a strike.

item.title: A Standoff at Libya’s Central Bank Shows Cracks in Country’s Political Stability
item.description: The country has settled into a tense east-west divide, but turmoil around the central bank, which handles Libya’s oil riches, has worsened a fraying, fragile political setup.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Islam Al-Atrash
item.media:description: The Central Bank of Libya, in Tripoli.

item.title: Russia Said It Repelled a Large Ukrainian Drone Attack as Offensive Advances
item.description: The attack came as Kyiv presses on with a cross-border offensive into western Russia that has rattled the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian army vehicle passes through the destroyed Russian border post at the Sudzha border crossing earlier this month.

item.title: Bus of Pilgrims From Pakistan Crashes in Iran, Killing at Least 28
item.description: Iranian state media reported that the passengers were traveling to the Iraqi city of Karbala for Arbaeen, a Shiite Muslim holiday.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: Thai Politician Is Under Fire After Slapping a Journalist on Camera
item.description: Videos of Prawit Wongsuwan, a former deputy prime minister, hitting a female reporter in the head prompted angry demands for an investigation in Thailand.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Wasu Vipoosanapat
item.media:description: Prawit Wongsuwan at the House of Representatives in Bangkok in 2023.

item.title: Gunman Kills 3 People at School in Bosnia
item.description: The attacker, a school employee, used a “military weapon, an automatic rifle” before then attempting to kill himself, a police spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Iranian Military Official Hints Strike on Israel May Be Delayed
item.description: The comments from an Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps leader suggested that a widely feared regional conflict might be averted, at least for the moment.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: The Revolutionary Guards during a military parade in Tehran.

item.title: Thailand Reports Mpox Case in Traveler Who Arrived From Africa
item.description: Officials are testing if the patient has the new version of the virus. If confirmed, it would be Thailand’s first case involving Clade Ib mpox.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: Thai officials are awaiting test results — likely due Friday — to determine if a recently arrived traveler has been infected with the Clade Ib version of mpox.

item.title: U.S. Push for Gaza Cease-Fire Falls Short on Key Points, Officials Say
item.description: Israeli and Hamas officials have downplayed the idea that a deal could be imminent, saying that mediators’ efforts have not resolved major disputes.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison, Ronen Bergman, Aaron Boxerman and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Smoke billowing following an Israeli strike on a hotel in Gaza City, on Tuesday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Hostilities between Israel and Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A home hit yesterday in Israeli-controlled Golan Heights.

item.title: Canada’s Freight Railroads Halt Operations Amid Labor Dispute
item.description: The shutdown could disrupt trade with the United States and other countries, as well as causing serious economic consequences within Canada.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A Canadian Pacific Kansas City railyard in British Columbia. Half of all Canadian exports are moved by train, according to an industry group.

item.title: A Ukrainian Combat Medic’s Quest to Change Fallen Soldier Tributes
item.description: Iryna Tsybukh, who was killed on the front line in Ukraine, wanted to humanize the way Kyiv commemorated the war dead. She also left notes for her own funeral.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Yermak
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carrying the coffin of Iryna Tsybukh, a Ukrainian combat medic, in Kyiv, Ukraine, in June.

item.title: The War in Gaza Is Making Thousands of Orphans
item.description: Extended families, hospital staff and volunteers are stepping in to care for Gaza’s many newly orphaned children, some of whom are injured, traumatized and haunted by memories of their parents.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Bilal Shbair
item.media:description: Palestinian children attending a recreational summer camp for orphaned children last month in the northern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Wilmer Puello-Mota, Ex-U.S. Airman Charged With Child Pornography, Appears in Russian Video
item.description: “I don’t consider myself a traitor,” said Wilmer Puello-Mota, who has enlisted in the Russian military.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: An image taken from a video posted on pro-Kremlin media sites appeared to show Wilmer Puello-Mota in a military enlistment office in Siberia.

item.title: Israel and Hezbollah Trade Cross-Border Strikes
item.description: The strikes, in eastern Lebanon and the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights, underscored how months of talks have failed to stop either the war in Gaza or the related conflict along the Lebanese border.
item.dc:creator: Gabby Sobelman and Euan Ward
item.media:description: A destroyed car and apartment building after an Israeli airstrike on Monday in Nabi Chit, Lebanon.

item.title: Andy Kim, Who Cleaned the Capitol After Jan. 6, Debuts on a Bigger Stage
item.description: The likely next senator from New Jersey spoke at the Democratic National Convention with a message about the importance of service and participation to safeguard democracy.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: Representative Andy Kim of New Jersey speaks at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago, Ill., on Wednesday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Russia Says Ukraine Aimed Drones at Moscow
item.description: Plus, China’s “road-trip auntie.”
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian army vehicle at the Sudzha border crossing earlier this month.

item.title: Pakistan Arrests Man Over Disinformation That Helped Spur U.K. Riots
item.description: Local police sources indicated that the arrest was made at the request of the British authorities, although there was no official confirmation.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Riot police officers holding back protesters in Southport, England, on July 30.

item.title: New Study Re-Evaluates ‘Worst Case’ Scenario for Thwaites Glacier
item.description: Global warming is putting the continent’s ice at risk of destruction in many forms. But one especially calamitous scenario might be a less pressing concern, a new study found.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: Snow blowing off the calving front of the Thwaites ice shelf in 2021.

item.title: Ultra-Orthodox Israelis Protest Conscription at Draft Center in Jerusalem
item.description: Protests over military conscription highlight the rising tensions surrounding a court order overturning a decades-long exemption for the religious community.
item.dc:creator: Gabby Sobelman and Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Israeli police officers in Jerusalem on Wednesday clashed with ultra-Orthodox men who were protesting conscription.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: The second night of the Democratic National Convention.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris made a video appearance from Milwaukee at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago last night.

item.title: Waterspout Was Seen When the Bayesian Yacht Sank in Sicily. What Is It?
item.description: Witnesses reported seeing the tornado-like phenomenon hit the Bayesian, a sailing yacht that sank off the coast of Sicily on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: Waterspouts are columns of spinning air that form on the water under thunderstorms.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: The U.S.’s Secret Nuclear Strategy
item.description: Plus, Ukraine’s women take over the work force.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis/The New York Times

item.title: Biden Approved Secret Nuclear Weapons Strategy Focusing on China
item.description: In a classified document approved in March, the president ordered U.S. forces to prepare for possible coordinated nuclear confrontations with Russia, China and North Korea.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Biden spent much of his political career as an advocate of nuclear nonproliferation and reducing the role of nuclear weapons in American defenses.

item.title: U.S. Sanctions Former Haitian President for Drug Trafficking
item.description: The Treasury Department said former President Michel Martelly’s actions have contributed significantly to the unraveling of security in the country.
item.dc:creator: David C. Adams
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michel Martelly in 2012, when he was the president of Haiti.

item.title: Ukrainian Lawmakers Pass Bill Aiming to Ban Russian-Aligned Church
item.description: The measure, which awaits President Volodymyr Zelensky’s signature, would further a long, post-Soviet split between two of the world’s largest Orthodox communities.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Sviatohirsk Monastery of the Caves, one of the holiest sites in the Russian Orthodox Church, overlooks the Siversky Donets River at Sviatohirsk in Ukraine’s eastern Donetsk region, in December.

item.title: Pakistan’s Internet Disruptions Stoke Fears of Government Surveillance
item.description: Disruptions have fueled claims from rights groups that the Pakistani authorities are introducing technology to surveil and control the country’s internet.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman and Christina Goldbaum
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Food-delivery drivers waiting near a restaurant in Islamabad, Pakistan, last week. The government is accused of throttling the internet while it tests new controls to crush dissent, digital researchers and analysts say.

item.title: Rocket Engine Explodes During Test at Shetland Spaceport
item.description: As European countries push to develop more independent space capabilities, a test at one new site produced an explosion.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel

item.title: Horticulturist Carlos Magdalena Is Saving Rare Flowers From Extinction
item.description: Carlos Magdalena, whose botanical adventures have shades of Indiana Jones, was a driving force in saving the world’s smallest water lily and finding the largest one. He has been called the “plant messiah.”
item.dc:creator: Silvana Paternostro
item.media:credit: Andrea DiCenzo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carlos Magdalena examining a giant Amazon water lily at the Princess of Wales Conservatory at Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, in London.

item.title: Maria Branyas Morera, World’s Oldest Person, Dies at 117
item.description: Ms. Branyas, who cultivated a following on social media as “Super Catalan Grandma,” died peacefully in her sleep, her family said.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Residencia Santa Maria Del Tura De Olot, via Reuters
item.media:description: Maria Branyas Morera celebrating her 117th birthday in March.

item.title: Kenyan Accused of Serial Killings Escapes From Police Custody
item.description: The police think that the suspected killer, Collins Jumaisi Khalusha, may have had help breaking out. A manhunt was underway.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Collins Jumaisi Khalusha, center, at a hearing in Kenya last month.

item.title: Hit Chinese Video Game, ‘Wukong’ Seeks to Curb ‘Negative Discourse’
item.description: Black Myth: Wukong tried to forbid influential overseas streamers from discussing “feminist propaganda,” Covid-19 and China’s video game industry policies.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu
item.media:description: A promotional image of a character from the video game Black Myth: Wukong. It is considered China’s first “AAA,” big-budget game.

item.title: Zelensky Says Ukraine Now Controls About 480 Square Miles of Russian Territory
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine seized on the incursion’s success to press allies to lift a longtime restriction: the use of Western-supplied long-range weapons against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian military vehicles behind a sign reading “Ukraine” and “Russia” near a destroyed border post at Sudzha, western Russia, this month.

item.title: Tropical Depression Jongdari Nears South Korea, Bringing Threat of Flooding
item.description: The storm has caused flight cancellations in the country’s south. It is forecast to skirt the west coast before making landfall on Wednesday near Seoul.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: High waves on Jeju Island, South Korea, on Tuesday, as Tropical Storm Jongdari approached.

item.title: The Bitter Fight Over the Meaning of ‘Genocide’
item.description: Debates over how to describe conflicts in Gaza, Myanmar and elsewhere are channeling a controversy as old as the word itself.
item.dc:creator: Linda Kinstler
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: War Is Draining Ukraine’s Male-Dominated Work Force. Enter the Women.
item.description: More and more women are replacing men mobilized in the army. But there are not enough of them to make up for the labor shortage affecting the economy.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: Switzerland Offers Reward for Ideas to Remove Old Bombs From Its Lakes
item.description: Switzerland is offering $58,000 in prize money for ideas to remove munitions from the depths, in case they start polluting. The catch: The cure can’t be worse than the problem.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Most of the ammunition lies at the bottom of three bodies of water: Lake Brienz, above; Lake Lucerne; and Lake Thun.

item.title: Blinken Pushes for Gaza Cease-Fire With Visits to Egypt and Qatar
item.description: After meetings in Israel, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken was pressing Hamas’s leadership through intermediaries to continue talks on the deal.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison

item.title: Israel Says It Recovered Bodies of 6 Hostages in Gaza
item.description: The bodies were retrieved in an overnight operation in southern Gaza, the Israeli military said. Five of the hostages were already known to have died in captivity.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Protesters calling for the release of hostages, in Tel Aviv on Monday.

item.title: Divers Search Bayesian for Mike Lynch and 5 Others Lost in Sicily Yacht Sinking
item.description: The body of the vessel’s cook was recovered while divers searched the hull of the Bayesian for passengers, including the tech entrepreneur Mike Lynch.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Emergency services working on Tuesday near where a yacht sank off Porticello, near the Sicilian capital, Palermo.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: The U.S. push for a cease-fire in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Antony J. Blinken, left, the U.S. secretary of state, with President Isaac Herzog of Israel at a Tel Aviv news conference yesterday.

item.title: They Ran a Campaign in Hiding. Now They Wait.
item.description: The campaign officials for Venezuela’s opposition have sheltered in an Argentine diplomatic residence in Caracas for five months, watching the country’s turmoil from asylum.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: Humberto Villalobos, Omar González, Claudia Macero, Magalli Meda and Pedro Urruchurtu at the Argentine diplomatic residence in Caracas.

item.title: Mexico’s Judges Vote to Strike, Opposing Overhaul of Legal System
item.description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador wants judges elected, not appointed. Court workers have already walked out to protest his plan, which critics call a power grab.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Striking judiciary workers in front of the Federal Judicial Branch building in Mexico City on Monday.

item.title: Iran Is to Blame for Hacking Into Trump’s Campaign, Intelligence Officials Say
item.description: American intelligence agencies also confirmed that the effort extended to the Biden-Harris campaign, though that bid was unsuccessful.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: The finding that Iran had breached the campaign of former President Donald J. Trump was widely expected.

item.title: Israel Accepts Proposal to Bridge Differences on Cease-Fire, Blinken Says
item.description: The statement by the secretary of state put new pressure on Hamas, whose officials have called the proposal fundamentally slanted toward Israel.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison, Isabel Kershner, Aaron Boxerman and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken in Tel Aviv on Monday. He pushed what he called “probably the best, maybe the last, opportunity” for a deal to end the fighting in Gaza and free hostages held by Hamas.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: U.S. Said Israel Agreed to Cease-Fire Proposal
item.description: Plus, opening night at the Democratic convention.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken with President Isaac Herzog of Israel yesterday.

item.title: Nicaragua Shutters 1,500 NGOs, Many of Them Churches
item.description: The government of President Daniel Ortega revoked the legal status of hundreds of evangelical groups as part of its crackdown on institutions that do not bow to its authority.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: The government led by President Daniel Ortega, right, and his wife, Vice President Rosario Murillo, has cracked down on civic and religious groups.

item.title: Hamas and Islamic Jihad Claim Responsibility for Tel Aviv Bombing
item.description: The two groups described the attack as a suicide bombing, but an Israeli statement did not. If confirmed, it would be the first suicide bombing in Israel in roughly eight years.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Gabby Sobelman
item.media:description: The Israeli police at the site of a bombing late Sunday in Tel Aviv.

item.title: Philippines Reports First Mpox Case Since W.H.O. Declared Global Emergency
item.description: It was not clear if the patient had contracted the new, potentially more deadly strain of the disease, which first appeared outside of Africa in Sweden last week.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: The Geneva-based World Health Organization declared mpox a global health emergency, last week.

item.title: Palestinian Woman and Her 6 Children Are Killed in Israeli Strike, Family Says
item.description: A Palestinian teacher and all her children were killed in a strike in Deir al-Balah that the Israeli military said had targeted “a significant Islamic Jihad terrorist.”
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek and Abu Bakr Bashir

item.title: Ukraine Attacks Bridges in Russia’s Kursk Region, Aiming to Encircle Troops
item.description: The attacks aim to destroy or damage crossings over a river in the Kursk region that are Russian forces’ only routes for resupply or retreat, military analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A satellite image showing a gap in a bridge over the Seym River on Saturday after a Ukrainian strike in the Kursk region of Russia.

item.title: Tech Entrepreneur Mike Lynch Among 6 Missing After Yacht Sinks Off Sicily
item.description: Fifteen other people were rescued. Expert divers were called in to carry out search operations in the deep water. Among the missing was a British software mogul, Mike Lynch.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Emergency services working near where a yacht sank in the early hours of Monday off Porticello, near the Sicilian city of Palermo.

item.title: Ukraine Says Its Incursion Will Bring Peace. Putin’s Plans May Differ.
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky wants to hold Russian territory as leverage in future talks. In Moscow, many doubt the strategy.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer, Kim Barker and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops riding atop a tank on the main road near the Russian border in the Sumy region of Ukraine last week.

item.title: Survivors of Doomsday Starvation Cult Testify Against Pastor and 93 Associates
item.description: An evangelical pastor in Kenya ordered his flock to shun education and medicine and starve their children to death in order to meet Jesus, witnesses in a manslaughter trial said.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Since April last year, 429 bodies have been exhumed from shallow graves in the Shakahola Forest in southeastern Kenya, where members of a doomsday cult lived.

item.title: The Mennonites Making the Amazon Their Home
item.description: Groups of Mennonites, seeking inexpensive land far from modern life, are carving out new colonies in the Amazon. They are also raising fears that they are adding to the deforestation of the vital jungle.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj and Marco Garro

item.title: A Crackdown in Kuwait After a Fatal Fire Is Hurting Migrant Laborers
item.description: After the blaze killed 49 migrant workers, a government crackdown focused on building violations — bypassing deeper problems that leave migrants with low wages and unsafe housing across the oil-rich Gulf.
item.dc:creator: Yasmena Almulla and Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Relatives mourning next to the coffins of Indian workers killed in a fire in June in Kuwait after they arrived in Kochi, India.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: The United Center, in Chicago, will be the main site for the Democratic National Convention.

item.title: Sparing the Horse, Brussels Warms Up to the Electric Carriage
item.description: The city’s last horse-drawn carriage operator says business is good since making the switch, placing the Belgian capital in the vanguard of a global change.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals
item.media:description: A driver of one of the first electric carriages in the Belgian capital, Brussels, taking tourists on a sightseeing tour in June.
